snippet.textDisplay: This is perfect! I didn't want to go to the store, and online is sold out of cording or price gouged! But I had a few pieces of cotton fabric from clothes I was planning to send to goodwill and I used a drawstring from an old pair of pajamas for the cord. I had some wire, but I imagine some bread clip wire would also work in a pinch! Thanks so much for all your efforts here and at the hospital! Much love.
snippet.textOriginal: This is perfect! I didn't want to go to the store, and online is sold out of cording or price gouged! But I had a few pieces of cotton fabric from clothes I was planning to send to goodwill and I used a drawstring from an old pair of pajamas for the cord. I had some wire, but I imagine some bread clip wire would also work in a pinch! Thanks so much for all your efforts here and at the hospital! Much love.

snippet.textDisplay: I love the idea of gathers with the cord rather than pleats and that the cord makes it adjustable to any head size. I will be making these today, but with a change to the filter pocket.  I am concerned  by the big hole in the middle of the mask made by the filter pocket if you/the person you give it to don't/doesn't actually insert a filter.  You basically have reduced your coverage to 1 layer of cotton fabric because the airflow will go right through the hole.  I've seen other patterns where the filter pocket has an overlay of an inch or so of the lining fabrics at the opening, or the pocket is at the bottom or sides of the mask instead of directly over the mouth and nose.
snippet.textOriginal: I love the idea of gathers with the cord rather than pleats and that the cord makes it adjustable to any head size. I will be making these today, but with a change to the filter pocket.  I am concerned  by the big hole in the middle of the mask made by the filter pocket if you/the person you give it to don't/doesn't actually insert a filter.  You basically have reduced your coverage to 1 layer of cotton fabric because the airflow will go right through the hole.  I've seen other patterns where the filter pocket has an overlay of an inch or so of the lining fabrics at the opening, or the pocket is at the bottom or sides of the mask instead of directly over the mouth and nose.

snippet.textDisplay: By far the easiest pattern I've seen.  Thank you for sharing and may God bless you and keep you safe!
snippet.textOriginal: By far the easiest pattern I've seen.  Thank you for sharing and may God bless you and keep you safe!

snippet.textDisplay: I made this mask for my son who works at the hospital. He was wanting something to be worn over the N-95 mask for added protection.  He said it worked great!   Because of the the cord it’s able to conform to any mask that is worn under it and to any person, man or woman. He liked that it came a bit lower over the chin.   I used para-chord for the ties.  For the filter my son brought me the wraps they use to sterilize surgical instruments. It was something that they throw away after a few uses.  I was able to get 50 6.5” squares double thickness out of one wrap.   Thanks for a great pattern!
snippet.textOriginal: I made this mask for my son who works at the hospital. He was wanting something to be worn over the N-95 mask for added protection.  He said it worked great!   Because of the the cord it’s able to conform to any mask that is worn under it and to any person, man or woman. He liked that it came a bit lower over the chin.   I used para-chord for the ties.  For the filter my son brought me the wraps they use to sterilize surgical instruments. It was something that they throw away after a few uses.  I was able to get 50 6.5” squares double thickness out of one wrap.   Thanks for a great pattern!

snippet.textDisplay:
I made a few minor changes.
1. I'm using 100 threat count cloth and I can't get it to bunch properly to create a loose seal on the sides of the mask, so instead of three layers, I'm only doing two layers.
2. I'm making masks for my kids (you know, the silent carriers) and they hate feeling strangled so 2. I put a two knots on the neck/down side of the mask so the bunches don't cut off their air.
3. I washed my first four masks and the wires started sticking out, so instead of folding the wire, I'm wrapping the ends around the tip of needle-nosed pliers to make a small circle -- then I hand sew that into place.
4. I can't get the neat corner-tuck that she's using to stay in place so I sew the corners down before I start.
5. I find that if the "underside" materials meet, then after going through the washer and the dryer they gap. Now I'm overlapping them by an inch or so.
snippet.textOriginal:
I made a few minor changes. 
1. I'm using 100 threat count cloth and I can't get it to bunch properly to create a loose seal on the sides of  the mask, so instead of three layers, I'm only doing two layers. 
2. I'm making masks for my kids (you know, the silent carriers) and they hate feeling strangled so 2. I put a two knots on the neck/down side of the mask so the bunches don't cut off their air.
3. I washed my first four masks and the wires started sticking out, so instead of folding the wire, I'm wrapping the ends around the tip of needle-nosed pliers to make a small circle -- then I hand sew that into place.
4. I can't get the neat corner-tuck that she's using to stay in place so I sew the corners down before I start.
5. I find that if the "underside" materials meet, then after going through the washer and the dryer they gap. Now I'm overlapping them by an inch or so.

snippet.textDisplay: Just make sure to put the mask in a sock before washing because they can get really tangled and break the wire. I had to rip mine out and fix it cause I didn't think to do this first. Aluminum wire may be a bit softer than the garden wire but if you have it on hand you can repair easily

snippet.textDisplay: I am a nurse as well and I shared this on my community helps page and people all over our city are making them! My daughter made the cutest "instructional cartoon" to hand out with the masks! I wasn't able to attach the picture here, however if you or anyone wants an email copy to print, please let me know! (linnfam5@roadrunner.com). I printed them on card stock (2 to a sheet) and loaded the mask, filter paper and refills, and the instructional sheet in a baggie to be distributed. Thanks for all you do!

snippet.textDisplay: Really love this pattern. I, myself is getting tired of making pleats because they are time consuming. For the chords, cotton shirts and knit fabrics will work too. snippet.textDisplay: I just made this and LOVE it.......but for the inside I wanted an overlapping pocket for filter so I cut 2 pcs of fabric 10x5" and pressed over the 10" edge of one side each piece 1/4" then folded again on itself 1/4" and stitched. Place right sides together of outside and inside fabric with 10" raw edges on top and bottom to make an overlapping pocket for filter. Stitch 1/4" all around, clip corners. Turn right side out and press, then finished per your instructions. I didnt have cording so I cut two 1" strips horizontally from and old t-shirt, pull to curl and stretch, then knot the ends. Mens sz L made strips approx 68" once stretched. I also used ToolBox brand blue shop towel folded in half for filter, 4" pc flat metal closure from bag of coffee for nose piece, and a cotton fat quarter for mask. Thank you so much for sharing this! Please stay safe everyone! 🥰
snippet.textOriginal: I just made this and LOVE it.......but for the inside I wanted an overlapping pocket for filter so I cut 2 pcs of fabric 10x5" and pressed over the 10" edge of one side each piece 1/4" then folded again on itself 1/4" and stitched. Place right sides together of outside and inside fabric with 10" raw edges on top and bottom to make an overlapping pocket for filter. Stitch 1/4" all around, clip corners. Turn right side out and press, then finished per your instructions. I didnt have cording so I cut two 1" strips horizontally from and old t-shirt, pull to curl and stretch, then knot the ends. Mens sz L made strips approx 68" once stretched. I also used ToolBox brand blue shop towel folded in half for filter, 4" pc flat metal closure from bag of coffee for nose piece, and a cotton fat quarter for mask. Thank you so much for sharing this! Please stay safe everyone! 🥰

snippet.textDisplay: Finished one.  Maybe it is the fabric I used, but the corners folded into 45 angle makes bulky corners .  I'm wondering if several hours of wear could cause soreness?  I think the next one I do will not have folded corners.  Also, I had difficulty with your mixed media instructions.  You mix speaking instructions with those printed on the screen.  I found it necessary to rewind the video several, several times to understand where you stopped talking and where the screen instructions coordinated.  I think it would be helpful to hear you speak ALL the instructions and then if the student is not ready to move on to the next step when you start talking about it, the video can be stopped.
snippet.textOriginal: Finished one.  Maybe it is the fabric I used, but the corners folded into 45 angle makes bulky corners .  I'm wondering if several hours of wear could cause soreness?  I think the next one I do will not have folded corners.  Also, I had difficulty with your mixed media instructions.  You mix speaking instructions with those printed on the screen.  I found it necessary to rewind the video several, several times to understand where you stopped talking and where the screen instructions coordinated. snippet.textDisplay: saw someone make  nose pieces, by  cutting  strips from those disposable aluminum baking pans, then folding them in the same way that bias tape is folded (but narrower) so all the sharp edges are hidden inside. On the ends, too. It looked pretty good. A flat, shiny metal strip. You could get quite a few from the bottom of a frozen pie plate or a turkey roaster pan. Because it's aluminum, it won't rust, when you wash the mask. I've worked with  that Ty wire, in fencing repairs. It has an oily coating, but it does rust, eventually.

snippet.textDisplay: Thank you for this pattern!  I made two today, washing more fabric for tomorrow.  One suggestion.  I tried the 3/16 clothesline and found that it didn't stay tied in the back.  I used t-shirt material that I had sliced horizontally into 2 inch strips instead.  It rolls nicely, was comfortable, and stayed tied.  Just an idea in case people are looking for a substitution for the cord.  Thanks again for this idea!!
snippet.textOriginal: Thank you for this pattern!  I made two today, washing more fabric for tomorrow.  One suggestion.  I tried the 3/16 clothesline and found that it didn't stay tied in the back.  I used t-shirt material that I had sliced horizontally into 2 inch strips instead.  It rolls nicely, was comfortable, and stayed tied.  Just an idea in case people are looking for a substitution for the cord.  Thanks again for this idea!!

snippet.textDisplay: I had no "cord"  that would work and of course all the stores are closed.  Then I thought of shoe strings and I even found those at the grocery store (54 inches)  4 for $2,00,  They work great and are easy to tie.  My masks are for family only, so don't expect to sterilize them...just wash and iron dry.  Hope this helps someone else who finds their sewing cabinet a little short on supplies.

snippet.textDisplay: Obtaining the filter material.is a problem. I checked they're not available until late May or June. I'm high risk, I've made a couple handkerchief masks. An idea popped into my head a few days ago, coffee filters, not the old accordion style but the new cone shaped filters I checked and could breather fine through the handkerchief folded in three layers and two layers of the coffee filters. My Sister is an RN and thinks it's a great idea, not 100% virus proof but quite a bit better than day 75% . What are your thoughts? The filters are tightly woven paper

snippet.textDisplay: Does the floral wire over the nose really make that big of difference?  I'd like to order supplies to make these for donation to the Joann Stores' Face Mask Make-To-Give effort, but the more I think about having a piece of metal over the nose, the more I wonder about rusting after repeated washing. I wouldn't want to put the people who wear these at risk of inhaling rust particles through the mask...  Some other YT videos I've seen are suggesting pipe cleaners since they hold their shape too, but these are probably going to rust after washing, and I'm guessing floral wire will too.  :(
snippet.textOriginal: Does the floral wire over the nose really make that big of difference?  I'd like to order supplies to make these for donation to the Joann Stores' Face Mask Make-To-Give effort, but the more I think about having a piece of metal over the nose, the more I wonder about rusting after repeated washing. I wouldn't want to put the people who wear these at risk of inhaling rust particles through the mask...  Some other YT videos I've seen are suggesting pipe cleaners since they hold their shape too, but these are probably going to rust after washing, and I'm guessing floral wire will too.  :(

snippet.textDisplay: Can you use parachute cording for the mask?  Also, do you need to use 55" for each mask?
snippet.textOriginal: Can you use parachute cording for the mask?  Also, do you need to use 55" for each mask?

snippet.textDisplay: Love this. BUT ... here are my changes and comments. 1)  I think the mask needs to be wider to make sure to seal the sides of the face. If I cut it 8x11 I can cut four pieces WOF (width of fabric). So I cut 1 strip 11” wide WOF, then sub cut into 4 8” pieces. 2) I think the length needs to be 60” instead of 55”. 3) it’s very important to not skimp on the 3/4” fold over on the sides. And make sure to sew it right near the edge - almost top stitching it. The reason is that the cord needs to slide EASILY  to pull it tight. I was too tight on the first mask and it was difficult to get one side to pull because the channel was too narrow. 4) I used 3mm macrame cord which worked well and is ridiculously inexpensive. Next I tried the synthetic clothesline and it slides better, but it’s more expensive. The 550 paraglide cord works best and it’s inexpensive on a large spool.  5) There is a trick to pulling the mask tight. ... this is the one and only thing that concerns me making it in bulk. I think it would need a little instruction, or a YouTube link. Could you please make a companion video that is 30-50 seconds long just showing how to put the mask on and pull it tight? I have made 13 mask prototypes to date and this is my favorite fast mask!!!! I like the Olson mask best but it’s longer to make. Well done and thank you!!! I’m now a subscriber to your channel, and I’m passing this video onto others.
snippet.textOriginal: Love this. BUT ... here are my changes and comments. 1)  I think the mask needs to be wider to make sure to seal the sides of the face. If I cut it 8x11 I can cut four pieces WOF (width of fabric). So I cut 1 strip 11” wide WOF, then sub cut into 4 8” pieces. 2) I think the length needs to be 60” instead of 55”. 3) it’s very important to not skimp on the 3/4” fold over on the sides. And make sure to sew it right near the edge - almost top stitching it. The reason is that the cord needs to slide EASILY  to pull it tight. I was too tight on the first mask and it was difficult to get one side to pull because the channel was too narrow. 4) I used 3mm macrame cord which worked well and is ridiculously inexpensive. Next I tried the synthetic clothesline and it slides better, but it’s more expensive. The 550 paraglide cord works best and it’s inexpensive on a large spool.  5) There is a trick to pulling the mask tight. ... this is the one and only thing that concerns me making it in bulk. I think it would need a little instruction, or a YouTube link. Could you please make a companion video that is 30-50 seconds long just showing how to put the mask on and pull it tight? I have made 13 mask prototypes to date and this is my favorite fast mask!!!! I like the Olson mask best but it’s longer to make. Well done and thank you!!! I’m now a subscriber to your channel, and I’m passing this video onto others.
